title: Prostate Cancer: MRI
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: An MRI is a test that produces very clear pictures of the human body without the use of X-rays. Instead, MRI uses a large magnet, radio waves, and a computer to produce these images.
In prostate cancer patients, MRI may be used to examine the prostate and nearby lymph nodes to distinguish between benign (noncancerous) and malignant (cancerous) areas.

content_blocks.text: An MRI is a test that produces very clear pictures of the human body without the use of X-rays. Instead, MRI uses a large magnet, radio waves, and a computer to produce these images.
In prostate cancer patients, MRI may be used to examine the prostate and nearby lymph nodes to distinguish between benign (noncancerous) and malignant (cancerous) areas.

sections.heading: Is MRI Examination Safe?
content: Yes. The MRI examination poses no risk to the average patient if appropriate safety guidelines are followed.
People who have had heart surgery and people with the following medical devices can be safely examined with MRI:
Some conditions may make an MRI examination not a good idea. Tell your doctor if you have any of the following conditions:
bullets: Cardiac valve replacements (except the Starr-Edwards metallic ball/cage)
Cerebral aneurysm clip (metal clip on a blood vessel in the brain)
Implanted insulin pump (for treatment of diabetes), narcotics pump (for pain medication), or implanted nerve stimulators (TENS) for back pain
Metal in the eye or eye socket, or metal near any major artery
Severe lung disease (such as tracheomalacia or bronchopulmonary dysplasia)
Not being able to lie on back for 30 to 60 minutes
Claustrophobia (fear of closed or narrow spaces)

content_blocks.text: Yes. The MRI examination poses no risk to the average patient if appropriate safety guidelines are followed.

associated_bullets: Cerebral aneurysm clip (metal clip on a blood vessel in the brain)
Implanted insulin pump (for treatment of diabetes), narcotics pump (for pain medication), or implanted nerve stimulators (TENS) for back pain
Metal in the eye or eye socket, or metal near any major artery
Severe lung disease (such as tracheomalacia or bronchopulmonary dysplasia)
Not being able to lie on back for 30 to 60 minutes
Claustrophobia (fear of closed or narrow spaces)

sections.heading: How Long Is the MRI Exam?
content: Allow one and a half hours for your MRI exam. In most cases, the procedure takes 45 to 60 minutes, during which several dozen images may be taken.

content_blocks.text: Allow one and a half hours for your MRI exam. In most cases, the procedure takes 45 to 60 minutes, during which several dozen images may be taken.

sections.heading: What Happens Before the Exam?
content: Personal items such as your watch, wallet (including any credit cards with magnetic strips - should not be brought into the room with the MRI machine in it.The credit cards will be erased by the magnet), and jewelry should be left at home or removed prior to the MRI scan. Secured lockers should be available to store personal items.

Secured lockers should be available to store personal items.

sections.heading: What Happens During the Exam?
content: You will be asked to wear a hospital gown during the MRI scan.

sections.heading: What Happens During the Exam?
content: You will be asked to wear a hospital gown during the MRI scan.

content_blocks.text: You will be asked to wear a hospital gown during the MRI scan.

content: As the MRI scan begins, you will hear the equipment making a muffled thumping sound, which will last for several minutes. Other than the sound, you should notice no unusual sensations during the scanning.
Certain MRI exams require an injection of a dye (contrast material). This helps identify certain anatomic structures on the scan images.

content_blocks.text: As the MRI scan begins, you will hear the equipment making a muffled thumping sound, which will last for several minutes. Other than the sound, you should notice no unusual sensations during the scanning.
Certain MRI exams require an injection of a dye (contrast material). This helps identify certain anatomic structures on the scan images.

content: Before the exam, feel free to ask questions and tell the technician or doctor if you have any concerns.

People who get anxious when in tight spaces ( claustrophobic ) may benefit from talking to their doctor before the procedure. Some options include taking a prescription medication before the procedure to relieve anxiety or having the exam done in one of the newer and less confining MRI units, called an open MRI, when available.

content_blocks.text: Before the exam, feel free to ask questions and tell the technician or doctor if you have any concerns.

Some options include taking a prescription medication before the procedure to relieve anxiety or having the exam done in one of the newer and less confining MRI units, called an open MRI, when available.

sections.heading: What Happens After the Exam?
content: You should be able to resume your usual activities immediately. Your doctor will discuss the test results with you.

content_blocks.text: You should be able to resume your usual activities immediately. Your doctor will discuss the test results with you.

meta_description: WebMD explains the use of MRI to examine the prostate for signs of prostate cancer.
